result.execSummary:
The defendant Keesha Marie McGowan was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manuf/Deliver Amphetamine(<=3g) [Modifiers: Second and Subsequent Offense], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(e)1.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Costs, service fees and DNA surcharge.

Not allowed to vote or serve in a jury until civil rights are restored. No possession or consumption of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid Rx and with the agent approval. Allowed emergency medication only. Not allowed to possess or consume anything that is illegal in WI. No entry in any bars, taverns or liquor store or any establishment whose primary purpose is the sale of alcohol. If at a restaurant no one sitting at the table is allowed to drink. No contact with known drug users unless in a treatment setting.

Complete compliance with all conditions of the Treatment Drug Court. Assessments, counseling and follow through as recommended by agent. Assessments for AODA and mental health. Maintain/obtain full time employment. Remain current with any child support orders. Submit DNA sample by 7-18-2022.

timeConds.notes: 1 year jail- imposed and stayed to be used by Treatment Drug Court.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Keesha Marie McGowan

No possession or consumption of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription and with the agent approval.  Allowed emergency medication only.  Not allowed to possess or consume anything that is illegal in Wisconsin. 
No entry into any bars, taverns, liquor stores or any establishment whose primary purpose is the sale of alcohol.  If at a restaurant no one sitting at the table is allowed to drink.
